content.text:
Here are common AWS cost optimization strategies for your stack:

## Compute (EKS, Lambda, EC2)
- **EKS**: Use Spot instances for worker nodes, right-size node groups, enable cluster autoscaling
- **Lambda**: Optimize memory allocation, use ARM-based Graviton processors, implement proper timeout settings
- **EC2**: Use Reserved/Savings Plans for steady workloads, Spot instances for fault-tolerant workloads, right-size instances based on CloudWatch metrics

## Storage & Database
- **S3**: Use Intelligent Tiering, lifecycle policies to move to cheaper storage classes (IA, Glacier), delete incomplete multipart uploads
- **RDS**: Use Reserved instances, right-size instances, enable storage autoscaling, consider Aurora Serverless for variable workloads

## Networking & Load Balancing
- **ALBs**: Consolidate load balancers where possible, use NLB for simple TCP traffic (cheaper than ALB)
- **Data Transfer**: Use CloudFront CDN to reduce data transfer costs, keep traffic within same AZ when possible
- **NAT Gateway**: Consider NAT instances for lower traffic scenarios, or VPC endpoints for AWS services

## Monitoring & Governance
- Set up Cost Budgets and alerts
- Use AWS Cost Explorer to identify spending trends
- Tag resources consistently for cost allocation
- Enable AWS Trusted Advisor recommendations
- Regular cleanup of unused resources (EBS snapshots, old AMIs, unused security groups)

## Quick Wins
- Delete unattached EBS volumes and old snapshots
- Stop/terminate unused EC2 instances
- Review and cancel unused Reserved instances
- Enable detailed billing and cost allocation tags
